claim: Electronics have become more affordable in the US since 1990.

supporting.text: The average price of consumer electronics such as televisions and computers has decreased significantly since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing technology and economies of scale.

attacks.text: The average price of consumer electronics such as televisions and computers has decreased significantly since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing technology and economies of scale.
While the average price has decreased, inflation-adjusted prices may not show as significant a decline when accounting for changes in purchasing power over time.
Inflation-adjusted data still shows a substantial decrease in prices for most consumer electronics, as technological advancements have outpaced inflation effects.
The decrease in average price does not account for the increased costs of high-end models and premium features, which may skew affordability perceptions.
Even high-end models today offer more advanced features at similar or lower prices compared to baseline models from the 1990s, improving overall affordability.

supporting.text: The introduction of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down the cost of electronics in the US market since 1990.

attacks.text: The introduction of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down the cost of electronics in the US market since 1990.
While costs have decreased for some electronics, inflation-adjusted prices for high-end devices (e.g., flagship smartphones) have actually risen since 1990.
Flagship smartphones represent a small fraction of the electronics market, and most consumer electronics (e.g., TVs, laptops) have seen significant price drops due to economies of scale.
Supply chain disruptions (e.g., during the COVID-19 pandemic) caused temporary price spikes, contradicting the steady decline implied by A2.
Temporary disruptions don't negate the long-term trend; post-pandemic prices returned to or fell below pre-pandemic levels for most electronics.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted data shows that electronic devices like smartphones and laptops are more affordable today than they were in 1990.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted data shows that electronic devices like smartphones and laptops are more affordable today than they were in 1990.
The inflation-adjusted data does not account for the hidden costs of ownership, such as required subscriptions, software updates, and accessories.
Many modern electronic devices include features that were previously sold separately, effectively reducing the total cost of ownership compared to the past.
The affordability claim is skewed by focusing only on high-end devices; budget electronics from the 1990s were often more durable and repairable, offering better long-term value.
Technological advancements have made even budget modern electronics far more capable than their 1990s counterparts, justifying any price differences.

supporting.text: The proliferation of budget-friendly electronics brands and products has expanded access to affordable technology for US consumers since 1990.

attacks.text: The proliferation of budget-friendly electronics brands and products has expanded access to affordable technology for US consumers since 1990.
Inflation-adjusted prices for many essential electronics components (e.g., semiconductors) have risen due to supply chain constraints and geopolitical factors.
Technological advancements and economies of scale have offset component cost increases, maintaining overall affordability.
Premium electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones) have seen price increases exceeding inflation, skewing average consumer costs.
Market segmentation ensures budget alternatives exist even as premium products increase in price.
